data.title: Chemistry of life - Learning goals
data.instruction: Click on the subtopic to see the learning goals.
data.subject: Science

goals.description:
State that cells are made up of proteins, carbohydrates, lipids, nucleic acids and vitamins.
List the main inorganic compounds in cells as water and minerals including calcium, sodium, potassium, phosphorus, iron, iodine, nitrate and phosphate ions.
Identify the main functions of water including being a universal solvent, transport medium for nutrients, and giving shape and volume to cells.
Describe the difference between macro and micro minerals.
Describe the main functions of the macro minerals and identify some mineral deficiency diseases of humans and plants.
Discuss the need for fertilisers in overused and leeched soil, and some consequences of using too much fertiliser.
Define organic molecules as those based on the element carbon, usually bonded to oxygen and hydrogen with some containing nitrogen and phosphorus.
goals.heading: After completing this subtopic you will be able to:

goals.description:
State that carbohydrates contain carbon, hydrogen and oxygen, and can be grouped as:
Monosaccharide (one molecule), example glucose and fructose.
Disaccharides (two monosaccharide molecules joined), examples sucrose and maltose.
Polysaccharides (more than two monosaccharide molecules joined), examples starch, cellulose and glycogen.
goals.heading: After completing this subtopic you will be able to:

goals.description:
State that lipids (fats and oils) are made up of a glycerol molecule attached to three fatty acids.
Explain how lipids may be saturated or unsaturated. 
Discuss the link between cholesterol in foods and heart disease.
goals.heading: After completing this subtopic you will be able to:

goals.description:
State that proteins contain carbon, hydrogen, oxygen and nitrogen, and some have phosphorus, sulfur and iron.
Describe how proteins are made up of amino acids arranged in polypeptide chains.
Describe the sensitivity of enzymes to pH and temperatures, and outline what happens when a protein is denatured.
Identify some of the many functions of proteins in the cell particularly as enzymes.
Describe the Lock and Key model for how enzymes work and their role in breaking down/synthesising molecules.
List some uses of enzymes in everyday life, for example, in washing powder.
goals.heading: After completing this subtopic you will be able to:

goals.description:
State that nucleic acids consist of carbon, hydrogen, oxygen, phosphorus and nitrogen. 
State that the two main nucleic acids are DNA and RNA.
goals.heading: After completing this subtopic you will be able to:

goals.description:
State that vitamins are organic molecules that are not made by the cells, but which are essential, in small amounts, for normal cellular function.
Discuss the role of vitamins A, C, D, E and one of the B vitamins in humans.
goals.heading: After completing this subtopic you will be able to:

goals.description:
Analyse the nutritional content on food nutrition labels. 
Compare the recommended daily allowance (RDA) of nutrients with your diet.
Draw a pie chart of food types in a diet.
goals.heading: After completing this subtopic you will be able to:

goals.description: Describe the laboratory procedures that can be used to identify carbohydrates (glucose and starch), lipids (fats) and proteins in common foods.
goals.heading: After completing this subtopic you will be able to:

goals.description: Design, measure and record results in an experiment to show the effect of temperature on hydrogen peroxide and the enzyme catalase in chicken liver.
